author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Evermore’ Returns to No. 1
description: Swift’s second surprise pandemic record has spent three of its four weeks out in the top spot of Billboard’s album chart.
content: One year turns into another. The sun rises in the east. And Taylor Swift is once again No. 1 on the Billboard album chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Manhunt Underway for Six Escaped California Inmates
description: The men used a rope made of braided bedsheets to scale the side of a jail.
content: Six men escaped from a jail in Merced County, Calif., using a rope of braided bedsheets, setting off a manhunt throughout the region, the authorities said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson and Scott McIntyre
title: A Miami Market Where the Fish Fly
description: Plaza Seafood is a hub of sounds, sustenance and a sense of community that are more in demand than ever during the pandemic.
content: MIAMI — Customers traveling by foot or convertible will hear Plaza Seafood Market shortly after it comes into view. The rhythmic thud of long, heavy knives cracking fish spines, landing hard on a cutting board, grows louder when you reach the parking lot, provided there are no motorcycles revving nearby, drowning everything else out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Davey Alba
title: How Parler, a Chosen App of Trump Fans, Became a Test of Free Speech
description: The app has renewed a debate about who holds power over online speech after the tech giants yanked their support for it and left it fighting for survival. Parler went dark early on Monday.
content: From the start, John Matze had positioned Parler as a “free speech” social network where people could mostly say whatever they wanted. It was a bet that had recently paid off big as millions of President Trump’s supporters, fed up with what they deemed censorship on Facebook and Twitter, flocked to Parler instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Colin Powell says he ‘can no longer call himself a Republican.’
description: Former Secretary of State Colin Powell said on Sunday, days after supporters of President Trump stormed the United States Capitol, that he no longer considers himself a member of the president’s party.
content: Former Secretary of State Colin Powell said on Sunday, days after supporters of President Trump stormed the United States Capitol, that he no longer considers himself a member of the president’s party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Dana Rubinstein
title: Superheroes and an Indoor Fund-Raiser: 5 Takeaways From the Mayor’s Race
description: With a big fund-raising deadline this week, the New York City mayoral candidates are under pressure to reach benchmarks that would qualify them for matching funds.
content: With the presidential race and the Senate elections in Georgia decided, the mayor’s race in New York City now takes center stage, with money in the starring role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Columbia Settles a Complicated Sexual Assault Case
description: The university restored the diploma of the accused man, but stands by its initial findings against him.
content: It began as a night of drinking and flirtation between two Columbia University classmates four years ago. It turned into a federal lawsuit with unusually detailed documentation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Impeachment Charge, Deserting Trump, Threats of Violence: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Tommy Lasorda’s Death Starts a Conversation About His Son
description: The Dodgers manager showed love for Tommy Jr., but publicly denied that he was gay and that he died of AIDS complications. Friends hope to honor the men by discussing their relationship.
content: When Penelope Spheeris heard that Tommy Lasorda died on Thursday at 93, she knew many people would be touched by the sad news, particularly in Los Angeles. The city has long been her home, and it is also where Lasorda became a baseball icon, leading the Dodgers to two World Series titles during his Hall of Fame career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Viscidi
title: Let’s Work With Latin America to Fight Climate Change
description: The Biden administration should support clean energy investments and environmental protections in the region.
content: Joe Biden has made clear that he will put climate change at the center of his domestic and foreign policy in a way that no previous president has. As a candidate, he proposed the most ambitious climate plan for any government in history, promising net zero emissions by 2050. As president-elect, he named former Secretary of State John Kerry as a cabinet-level official to manage climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold, Dana Rubinstein and Amanda Rosa
title: More New Yorkers start receiving the Covid-19 vaccine.
description: New York on Monday began giving vaccines to residents 75 and older as well as a wider range of essential workers, as state health officials expanded the group of people eligible to receive the vaccine.
content: New York on Monday began giving vaccines to residents 75 and older as well as a wider range of essential workers, as state health officials expanded the group of people eligible to receive the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Police Reassess Security for Inauguration and Demonstrations After Capitol Attack
description: In the wake of last week’s assault on the Capitol, Mayor Muriel E. Bowser of Washington called for officials to expedite security preparations for the inauguration.
content: Federal and local authorities across the country pressed their hunt this weekend for the members of the angry mob that stormed the Capitol building last Wednesday, as Washington’s mayor issued an urgent appeal to start preparing immediately for more potential violence before, during and after the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Facebook will remove ‘Stop the Steal’ misinformation.
description: Facebook announced on Monday that it plans to remove content centered around the “Stop the Steal” movement across its platform, as the social network prepares for a potentially quarrelsome presidential inauguration on January 20.
content: Facebook announced on Monday that it plans to remove content centered around the “Stop the Steal” movement across its platform, as the social network prepares for a potentially quarrelsome presidential inauguration on January 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Francisco Lindor Talks Mets, Pizza and Contract Extensions
description: In a news conference following his trade from Cleveland, the star shortstop showed enthusiasm for his new team and his new city.
content: Francisco Lindor was caught in an awkward position on Monday: eager to show enthusiasm about joining a new team while not forgetting about the one he left behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Who Are the 5 People Who Died in the Capitol Riot?
description: A police officer was beaten, a rioter was shot, and three others died during the rampage.
content: One had dreamed of becoming a police officer and was injured in a clash with rioters. One was an Air Force veteran and a fervent supporter of President Trump who was shot by the police. Three others were Trump loyalists — including one who sold kangaroos dressed like the president — who suffered what the authorities called “medical emergencies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘In a Pandemic Fairy Tale, a Garden Leads to a Magical Friendship’
description: In this lesson, students will meet a 4-year-old girl, her adult neighbor and a fairy named Sapphire. Then, they will consider the power of friendship and magical thinking — especially in these trying times.
content: Featured Article: “In a Pandemic Fairy Tale, a Garden Leads to a Magical Friendship” by Christina Morales
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: When an I.Q. Score Is a Death Sentence
description: The Supreme Court declared it was unconstitutional to execute intellectually disabled people. On Thursday, we’re set to do it anyway.
content: In January 1993, a psychologist asked Corey Johnson to write a story about a picture of an astronaut crouching on a lunar landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Head Into the Kitchen
description: Building your cooking practice improves moods, atmospheres and weeks alike — and it’s simple.
content: How goes it? These are challenging times, of course, made more so by the newness of the year that brings with it hope and optimism but also hard work: your new fitness challenge; your focus on self-care; your home office to-do list; your job search; your corporate goals for 2021. Some have stopped drinking for the month, one day after another, forever — it’s difficult. Some have vowed to eat more healthily, whatever that means: less meat, no meat, more vegetables, no dairy, no carbs. That, too, is complicated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Alzheimer’s Drug Shows Promise in Small Trial
description: Participants with the disease still declined, but much more slowly than those receiving a placebo, investigators say.
content: In a small clinical trial, an experimental Alzheimer’s drug slowed the rate at which patients lost the ability to think and care for themselves, the drug maker Eli Lilly announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Hundreds of Historians Join Call for Trump’s Impeachment
description: More than 300 historians and writers, including Ron Chernow and Taylor Branch, signed an open letter calling President Trump “a clear and present danger to American democracy.”
content: More than 300 historians and constitutional scholars have signed an open letter calling for the impeachment and removal of President Trump. They say his continuation in office after encouraging supporters to march on the U.S. Capitol posed “a clear and present danger to American democracy and the national security of the United States.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Impeachment Looms. What’s Next for the G.O.P.?
description: Three big factors will shape the party’s direction: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Trump has said he won’t be at the inauguration — but Democrats are hoping that by Jan. 20, he won’t even be president anymore. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: In Kashmir’s Stillness, Hopes Wither and Houseboats Sink
description: The turbulent region has long weathered violence and political strife, but India’s security crackdown and the coronavirus have brought life in the tourist-dependent region to a near halt.
content: SRINAGAR, India — Habib Wangnoo scanned the silvery lake from the deck of his vacant houseboat hotel, remembering when he helped Mick Jagger out of a narrow, flat-bottomed canoe during the rock star’s 1981 visit to Kashmir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Teachers: How Are You Explaining the Riot?
description: History teachers, civics teachers, and social studies teachers: Please share your stories.
content: We’re interested in how teachers, particularly history, social studies, or civics teachers, are addressing last Wednesday’s storming of the Capitol with their students. If you are talking with your students about this — either in free-form discussions or carefully crafted lessons — please write us and describe what you have done, or plan to do, with your students and how they have responded.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside the Billion-Dollar War Against Right-Wing Conspiracists
description: John Poulos is the C.E.O. of Dominion Voting Systems. His $1.3 billion suit against an ex-Trump lawyer might be the “first step” in a powerful fight against actual fake news.
content: Chief Executive John Poulos says Dominion Voting System’s $1.3 billion defamation suit against Sidney Powell is the “first step” in the voting machine company’s efforts to counter a “malicious campaign of lies” spread by right-wing media outlets and the conspiracy theorists in Donald Trump’s inner circle. Dominion is fighting disinformation surrounding the elections in Georgia, Michigan and elsewhere with a powerful weapon: the lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muktita Suhartono and Sui-Lee Wee
title: Indonesia gives emergency approval to a vaccine from a Chinese company.
description: Indonesia  authorized on Monday the emergency use of a Covid-19 vaccine made by a private Chinese company, after late-stage clinical data reaffirmed that the shot is effective. The step cleared the way for a mass vaccination program to begin in the country.
content: Indonesia  authorized on Monday the emergency use of a Covid-19 vaccine made by a private Chinese company, after late-stage clinical data reaffirmed that the shot is effective. The step cleared the way for a mass vaccination program to begin in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Pranshu Verma
title: William Burns, a career diplomat, is Biden’s choice to head the C.I.A.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden has selected William J. Burns, a career State Department official who led the U.S. delegation in secret talks with Iran, to run the Central Intelligence Agency.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden has selected William J. Burns, a career State Department official who led the U.S. delegation in secret talks with Iran, to run the Central Intelligence Agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Formalizes Women’s Roles, but Priesthood Stays Out of Reach
description: Pope Francis has amended the Catholic Church laws so that women may be Bible readers at Mass, serve at the altar and distribute communion — practices already common in many countries.
content: ROME — Pope Francis has changed the laws of the Roman Catholic church to formally allow women to give readings from the Bible during Mass, act as altar servers and distribute communion, but they remain barred from becoming deacons or priests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Group Takes Legal Action Over Lack of Abortion Services in Northern Ireland
description: A human rights group says the government’s inaction has left a health care void in a country where the procedure was legalized in 2019, but remains largely unavailable.
content: A human rights group in Northern Ireland is taking legal action against the government over its failure to provide abortion access, the group announced on Monday, highlighting the continuing struggle for safe abortions more than a year after the procedure was legalized in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Gillian Friedman
title: It Could Be a Great Year, if Your Business Survives Winter
description: Tough sacrifices may still be required, but many see a post-pandemic resurgence in the year ahead.
content: For Ashlie Ordonez, owner of the Bare Bar Studio, a spa in Denver, vaccinations for the coronavirus can’t come soon enough. While she anticipates better days later this year, surviving until then will be a struggle, and she knows the next few months will be lean ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: First Woman to Face Federal Execution Since 1953 Seeks Reprieve
description: Lisa M. Montgomery is seeking to have her sentence for a gruesome murder reduced to life imprisonment because she suffered sexual abuse from a young age. A federal judge issued a stay in her case late Monday.
content: WASHINGTON — In December 2004, Lisa M. Montgomery murdered a pregnant woman in Skidmore, Mo., and abducted the unborn child to claim as her own. The only woman on federal death row, she is scheduled for execution on Tuesday, and her defense team does not contest her guilt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Azi Paybarah
title: These Businesses and Institutions Are Cutting Ties With Trump
description: The P.G.A. and several large banks are among those that have disassociated themselves from the president since his supporters stormed the Capitol.
content: They have stripped President Trump of honorary degrees, a key conduit for campaign contributions and, in a stinging blow to the president’s resort business, one of golf’s four major tournaments, set for a Trump club in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Summerwater’ Makes an Intimate Study of Social Class Out of a Long, Rainy Day
description: In Sarah Moss’s new novel, shut-in vacationers in Scotland observe each other and the state of the world with suspicion.
content: Against the wisdom of the ages, you can tell a book by its cover. You can usually tell one by its title, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: Madrid Is Buried Under Heaviest Snowfall in 50 Years
description: At least three people have died after Storm Filomena wreaked havoc across Spain and blanketed the capital in more than a foot and a half of snow, paralyzing it for days.
content: The heaviest snowfall in five decades has blanketed Madrid over the past few days, after a giant storm hit southern and central Spain, causing at least three deaths and prompting the authorities to activate the highest level of weather warning in the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and James Wagner
title: A Stark Divide in California’s Surge
description: Monday: The state is having two distinct pandemics, north and south. Also, remembering Tommy Lasorda.
content: The numbers jump off the page. In the first week of this year, Los Angeles County recorded 950 deaths from the coronavirus — four times as many deaths as San Francisco has had during the entire pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Swartz
title: Never Forget What Ted Cruz Did
description: The senator has been able to use his Ivy League pedigree as a cudgel. After last week, his credentials should condemn him.
content: When I was growing up, I was often reminded that people with fancy educations and elite degrees “put their pants on one leg at a time just like the rest of us.” This was back in the early 1960s, before so many rich Texans started sending their kids to Ivy League schools, when mistrust of Eastern educated folks — or any highly educated folks — was part of the state’s deep rooted anti-intellectualism. Beware of those who lorded their smarts over you, was the warning. Don’t fall for their high-toned airs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines and Julie Bosman
title: Reeling From a Riot, Washington Faces Rising Coronavirus Cases
description: The district has seen more new cases in the last week than in any other seven-day stretch in the pandemic, part of a broader surge in the nation’s Mid-Atlantic region.
content: WASHINGTON — While Mayor Muriel E. Bowser of Washington, D.C., was grappling with the riot that tore through the Capitol last week, another crisis was slowly unfolding: a surge of coronavirus in the district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Rifkin
title: Thomas Verdillo, 77, Dies; Restaurateur Went from Red Sauce to Blue Ribbon
description: He put a refined twist on traditional Italian-American cooking at his South Brooklyn restaurant, Tommaso. He died of complications of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Pandemic Update: The Variant and the Vaccine Rollout
description: With the coronavirus at a peak in the United States, we look at the latest in the fight against the disease.
content: As 2020 drew to a close, a concerning development in the pandemic came out of Britain — a new variant of the coronavirus had been discovered that is significantly more transmissible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From the N.F.L.’s Wild-Card Weekend
description: Lamar Jackson finally won a playoff game, the Browns demolished the Steelers and Nickelodeon’s broadcast of a game for children offered a welcome distraction.
content: It was a supersize wild-card weekend, with the N.F.L.’s expanded playoff format requiring six games, rather than four, in the first two days of the postseason. There were no surprises in the results of the first five games, but Sunday night finished with a thrilling upset in which the Cleveland Browns won a playoff game for the first time in 26 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Stewart
title: The Roots of Josh Hawley’s Rage
description: Why do so many Republicans appear to be at war with both truth and democracy?
content: In today’s Republican Party, the path to power is to build up a lie in order to overturn democracy. At least that is what Senator Josh Hawley was telling us when he offered a clenched-fist salute to the pro-Trump mob before it ransacked the Capitol, and it is the same message he delivered on the floor of the Senate in the aftermath of the attack, when he doubled down on the lies about electoral fraud that incited the insurrection in the first place. How did we get to the point where one of the bright young stars of the Republican Party appears to be at war with both truth and democracy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Lies, Damn Lies, and Georgia
description: The election of Raphael Warnock and Jon Ossoff is a clear message: The South truly is changing.
content: NASHVILLE — It’s impossible not to notice how many members of Congress who voted to overturn the 2020 presidential election were white Southerners — more than half the legislators who professed to believe Donald Trump’s lie that the election was stolen are people who represent the American South. Even after his supporters, egged on by the president himself, staged a violent insurrection inside the United States Capitol, these craven, feckless legislators would not vote to certify the results of an election that has survived the scrutiny of more than 60 baseless challenges in various courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: 6 Park Rangers Ambushed and Killed in Congo Gorilla Reserve
description: The attack in the Virunga National Park was the latest assault on rangers charged with protecting one of Africa’s oldest nature areas.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — At least six rangers have been ambushed and killed in the Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, park officials said, part of a wave of violence that has plagued Africa’s oldest park and continues to endanger the home of around a third of the world’s mountain gorillas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Money Walks
description: Corporate America is rethinking its political donations.
content: Big businesses often donate to both political parties and say that their support is tied to narrow issues of specific interest to their industries. That became increasingly fraught last week, after a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol and some Republican lawmakers tried to overturn Joe Biden’s win in the presidential election. A flurry of companies have since reviewed political giving via their corporate political action committees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Why Are We So Afraid of Fevers?
description: Under most circumstances, fever is beneficial, reducing the severity of illness and shortening its length.
content: Among the many measures my local Y is using to prevent the spread of Covid-19, instant temperatures are taken with a forehead scanner before people can enter the building. Curious to know how “hot” I was one cold, rainy day, I asked the attendant what it registered: 96.2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Barry Goldsmith, Who Escaped, Dropped Out and Came Back, Dies at 82
description: Mr. Goldsmith survived the Holocaust, immigrated to the United States and built a successful career as an architect, before abandoning his life for a commune — and then coming home. He died of complications of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: The Spring Semester to Come
description: “The pandemic has shattered the security of the ivory tower.”
content: “The pandemic has shattered the security of the ivory tower,” said Anemona Hartocollis, who covers higher education for The Times. “There will be a sense of urgency about our coverage that we would not have in normal times.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The Attack on the Capitol Was Even Worse Than It Looked
description: As new and more graphic videos of the mayhem emerged on social media and TV, the enormity of what happened only deepened.
content: The live video of the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol was largely images from a distance: a sea of attackers seeping up the steps and through the entryways. It was like watching a malevolent tide slowly threaten to drown democracy. It could not possibly get worse than this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Pranshu Verma
title: William Burns Is Biden’s Choice for C.I.A. Director
description: The president-elect has decided to place the agency in the hands of a career Foreign Service officer who is well regarded by the rank and file.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected William J. Burns, a career State Department official who led the U.S. delegation in secret talks with Iran, to run the C.I.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Forced Online, an Opera Festival Searches for Intimacy
description: Prototype, known for presenting visceral, chamber-scale new works, unveils an almost entirely streamed pandemic edition.
content: The annual Prototype festival of new opera and music theater thrives on intimacy. Its chamber-scale offerings — often politically charged, emotionally brutal and just plain loud — vibrate the viscera. Prototype has become known for screaming, moaning works like “Angel’s Bone” and “Prism,” which both went on to win Pulitzer Prizes and were clench-your-jaw immersions in suffering, put on in tiny theaters that magnified their effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: With New Platform, Comics Entrepreneurs Hope to Boost Local Shops
description: A new comics shopping platform will offer live programming and bring attention to comic stores.
content: Comic book fans can look forward to another way of shopping on Saturday, when a new platform, the Comic Book Shopping Experience, debuts on Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How a Vogue Cover Created an Uproar Over Kamala Harris
description: The vice president-elect is on the cover of the U.S. fashion magazine. Many people are not happy with the result.
content: Though it might seem, in light of all that is going on currently in Washington, D.C., the least of the matter, on Sunday a leaked shot of Vice President-elect Kamala D. Harris’s Vogue cover set off an unexpected firestorm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Grown-Ups Loved the N.F.L. on Nickelodeon. But What About Children?
description: The cable channel aired a slime-filled version of the Bears-Saints wild-card game on Sunday, to the delight of many adults. But the goal was to convert children into football fans.
content: When Michael Thomas scored the first touchdown of Sunday’s wild-card game between the Chicago Bears and the New Orleans Saints, fans watching the game on CBS saw a close angle of him spiking the football. Fans watching on Nickelodeon, the children’s channel, saw something much more exciting: digital slime cannons spewing Nickelodeon’s signature green goo all over the end zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: HBO Max Orders a ‘Sex and the City’ Revival
description: Three of the original cast members will reprise their roles in the 10-episode series.
content: “Sex and the City,” the landmark HBO series that ran from 1998 through 2004 and was later made into two feature films, is returning yet again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Trump, Covid-19, U.K.: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Trump’s second impeachment.
content: Democrats in the House of Representatives initiated an effort to impeach President Trump for inciting a mob that attacked the Capitol last week. A vote on the measure could happen as early as Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Patriots’ Coach Belichick to Decline Presidential Award
description: President Trump had planned to give Belichick the Presidential Medal of Freedom this week, but the coach cited the violence at the Capitol last week in a statement announcing that he would not receive it.
content: New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick said in a statement Monday that he had turned down the opportunity to receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Trump because of the “tragic events of last week,” a reference to the rampage at the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Clowes
title: For British Drill Stars, the Police Are Listening Closely
description: Recent court rulings require officers to keep watch over artists’ rap lyrics, which prosecutors say celebrate gangs and violent crimes.
content: LONDON — The British rapper Digga D can’t explain how he lost the use of an eye while serving a prison sentence last year: not because he doesn’t want to, but because talking about what happened might get him sent back to jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Memphis Police Officer Is Charged With Kidnapping and Murder
description: Patric Ferguson, who had been with the department for over two years, kidnapped a man in the back of a squad car and shot him, the authorities said.
content: A Memphis police officer was fired and accused of kidnapping and killing a man while on duty, the authorities said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: The Washington Monument has been closed because of ‘credible threats.’
description: The National Park Service has closed the Washington Monument, citing “credible threats to visitors and park resources” around the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: The National Park Service has closed the Washington Monument, citing “credible threats to visitors and park resources” around the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Coons
title: The World Is Watching. We Need to Hold Trump Accountable.
description: We need to show our allies and adversaries that our democracy has weathered this test.
content: WASHINGTON — Jan. 6 was a dark day for American democracy. For only the second time in our republic’s history, our United States Capitol was ransacked, except this time it wasn’t by British troops. It was by a riotous mob of thugs, incited by our president, trying to stop the certification of the results of the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Chad Wolf has resigned as acting secretary for the Homeland Security Department.
description: The move came just nine days before Mr. Wolf was expected to help coordinate the security of a presidential inauguration facing heightened threats of violence.
content: Chad F. Wolf, the acting secretary for the Homeland Security Department, resigned on Monday, just nine days before he was expected to help coordinate the security of a presidential inauguration facing heightened threats of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Nicole Perlroth
title: Parler Accuses Amazon of Breaking Antitrust Law in Suspending Hosting Services
description: The social network, which had fast been gaining right-wing users, said that Amazon had conspired with Twitter, but did not provide any direct evidence.
content: Hours after it went offline on Monday, the social media start-up Parler filed a lawsuit in federal court accusing Amazon of violating antitrust law and asking for a temporary restraining order to prevent the tech giant from blocking access to cloud computing services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: What Did Museum Sign Up For: Exhibition or Investigation?
description: As part of an exhibition at Miami Dade College’s art museum, Forensic Architecture planned to examine the treatment of migrant children at a nearby facility. The pandemic is only one reason that never happened.
content: If one vital function of art is to shake things up, look no further than an exhibition last year at the Museum of Art and Design at Miami Dade College in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Big companies pause their political contributions.
description: Several Wall Street banks and other companies have said they are reviewing their political giving after a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol building.
content: Big businesses often donate to both political parties and say their support is tied to narrow issues of specific interest to their industries. That practice became increasingly fraught last week, after a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol and some Republican lawmakers tried to overturn Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s win in the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Disqualification Question
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: If the House impeaches President Trump this week, it will still have almost no effect on how long he remains in office. His term expires nine days from now, and even the most rapid conceivable Senate trial would cover much of that time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: How the Right Foods May Lead to a Healthier Gut, and Better Health
description: A diet full of highly processed foods with added sugars and salt promoted gut microbes linked to obesity, heart disease and diabetes.
content: Scientists know that the trillions of bacteria and other microbes that live in our guts play an important role in health, influencing our risk of developing obesity, heart disease, Type 2 diabetes and a wide range of other conditions. But now a large new international study has found that the composition of these microorganisms, collectively known as our microbiomes, is largely shaped by what we eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
title: Washington has another problem: The coronavirus is surging in the capital.
description: While Mayor Muriel E. Bowser of Washington, D.C., was grappling with the riot that tore through the Capitol last week, another crisis was slowly unfolding in the district: a surge of coronavirus cases.
content: While Mayor Muriel E. Bowser of Washington, D.C., was grappling with the riot that tore through the Capitol last week, another crisis was slowly unfolding in the district: a surge of coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: An Appreciation for Vaccines, and How Far They Have Come
description: The DTP vaccine teaches us about how brilliant vaccine technology can be, but also how it can be studied and improved over time.
content: This time of year, my thoughts turn to the DTP vaccine. Last year I wrote about the apocryphal “Christmas miracle” of 1891, in which the newly discovered diphtheria antitoxin may (or more likely, may not) have been used before it had been approved to save a child’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Only Impeachment Can Save Republicans
description: If the G.O.P. doesn’t turn on Trump now, it will be tainted and crippled for years.
content: If there’s one thing Republicans in Congress ought to consider as they weigh the merits of impeaching Donald Trump, it’s the story of the president’s relationship with Mike Pence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: Moynihan Train Hall: It’s Stunning. And, a First Step.
description: A $1.6 billion transformation of a post office has gifted the city with a lofty, light-filled steel, glass and marble cathedral, our critic writes.
content: The $1.6 billion Moynihan Train Hall opened at dawn on New Year’s morning — on budget, too, even a couple of months early. Instagram swooned. Tweeters channeled Stefon from “Saturday Night Live.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio, Nicholas Fandos and David Leonhardt
title: Would impeachment prevent Trump from seeking office in the future? It’s complicated.
description: With just days remaining in his term, House Democrats have introduced an article of impeachment in Congress charging President Trump for a second time with committing “high crimes and misdemeanors,” this time for his role in inciting a mob that stormed the Capitol last week.
content: With just days remaining in his term, House Democrats have introduced an article of impeachment in Congress charging President Trump for a second time with committing “high crimes and misdemeanors,” this time for his role in inciting a mob that stormed the Capitol last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Helene Cooper
title: The Capitol Police chief says his pleas for backup were ignored by the sergeants-at-arms and the Pentagon.
description: The outgoing head of the Capitol Police requested that D.C. National Guard units be placed on standby in case his small force was overwhelmed by violent protesters last Wednesday, but  he was rebuffed by House and Senate security officials and a top Pentagon commander, he said in an interview on Sunday.
content: The outgoing head of the Capitol Police requested that D.C. National Guard units be placed on standby in case his small force was overwhelmed by violent protesters last Wednesday, but  he was rebuffed by House and Senate security officials and a top Pentagon commander, he said in an interview on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: A Colonoscopy Alternative Comes Home
description: An at-home test for colon cancer is as reliable as the traditional screening, health experts say, and more agreeable.
content: Most Americans who are due for a colon cancer screening will receive a postcard or a call — or prompting during a doctor’s visit — to remind them that it’s time to schedule a colonoscopy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Fox News to Add Another Hour of Right-Wing Talk as Biden Takes Office
description: The anchor Martha MacCallum will be replaced by a conservative host at 7 p.m., and CNN will expand Jake Tapper’s afternoon show.
content: Rupert Murdoch’s cable news channel said on Monday that it would revamp its daytime lineup starting next week, the week of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration, adding another hour of right-wing opinion as a lead-in to its prime-time stars Tucker Carlson and Sean Hannity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: The Most Important Thing Biden Can Learn From the Trump Economy
description: A “hot” economy with high deficits didn’t cause runaway inflation.
content: For all the problems that President Trump’s disdain of elite expertise has caused over the last four years, his willingness to ignore economic orthodoxy in one crucial area has been vindicated, offering a lesson for the Biden years and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Helene Cooper
title: Troops Flood a Rattled Washington Ahead of the Biden Inauguration
description: Chad F. Wolf, the head of the department overseeing the agency leading inauguration security, announced that he would resign as acting secretary on Monday night.
content: WASHINGTON — Law enforcement authorities, responding to threats of violence before the Jan. 20 presidential inauguration, will deploy up to 15,000 National Guard troops to the nation’s capital and set up checkpoints in the city to avoid the botched response that helped rioters overrun the Capitol last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: With Injury, Justin Fields Is Taking a Big Risk for Ohio State
description: The dynamics of college football mean that the quarterback will shoulder all of the downsides of playing in the title game after his painful injury in the semifinals.
content: [Follow our live score and game tracker of Alabama vs Ohio State.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: The talk radio network that airs Dan Bongino and Mark Levin warned staff to stop ‘dog-whistle talk.’
description: Cumulus Media warned employees at 416 stations that they would be fired if they continued to back Trump’s false claims of voter fraud.
content: Cumulus Media, a talk radio company with a roster of popular right-wing personalities including Dan Bongino, Mark Levin and Ben Shapiro, has ordered its employees at 416 stations nationwide to steer clear of endorsing misinformation about election fraud or using language that promotes violent protest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: After Rivals Pounce, Yang Explains His Family’s Escape From New York
description: Andrew Yang said that his family decided to leave the city during the pandemic in part to help his autistic son “adapt to our new normal.”
content: Andrew Yang could be days away from declaring himself a New York City mayoral candidate, but he’s already found himself on the defensive over his decision to spend significant parts of the pandemic in the Hudson Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: ‘It Was a Joke’: Some Small Businesses Got $1 Relief Loans
description: Sole proprietors were eligible for loans under the Paycheck Protection Program only if they were profitable, but many got tiny loans because of the way rules were written.
content: The Paycheck Protection Program was a lifeline for millions of small businesses brutalized by the pandemic. Over a four-month span, the government program distributed $523 billion in forgivable loans to more than five million companies. The average recipient got just over $100,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: On Taiwan’s New Passport, the Incredible Shrinking ‘Republic of China’
description: Officials said the redesign was an attempt to disassociate Taiwanese citizens from those on the mainland, who faced travel restrictions amid the pandemic.
content: Taiwan on Monday released a new passport that puts a diplomatic spin on the concept of social distancing amid the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: $60 Million High Line Expansion to Connect Park to Moynihan Train Hall
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo will propose a 1,200-foot elevated pathway that will lead to the new Penn Station development, to be financed by public and private funds.
content: For more than a decade, the High Line, an elevated park that stretches for nearly a mile and half through the West Side of Lower Manhattan, has been a symbol of ambitious urban renewal: a sleek, tree-lined walkway created from an old run-down rail line that cuts through once-industrial neighborhoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Marie Kondo Talks About Tidying Up in 2021 and Her New Product Launch
description: A partnership with the Container Store will offer a line of 100 organizing objects for people who ‘don’t have as many empty boxes.’
content: It was perhaps inevitable that Marie Kondo, the one-time Shinto shrine maiden turned tidiness guru and media powerhouse, would expand her organizing business into products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Senator Klobuchar to Write Antitrust Book
description: The Minnesota Democrat and former presidential candidate said her book would call for reform in how the United States treats monopolies and competition.
content: Alfred A. Knopf announced on Monday that Senator Amy Klobuchar, a Minnesota Democrat and former presidential candidate, will write about monopolies and her recommendations for how they should be challenged in a book slated for release in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: For Pro Athlete Leading Social Justice Push, a Victory and Uncertainty
description: Elizabeth Williams of the Atlanta Dream helped galvanize opposition to one of her team’s owners, Senator Kelly Loeffler, who has criticized Black Lives Matter. But the Capitol riot underscored the work ahead.
content: The challenge seemed simple and direct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: These Snakes Found a New Way to Slither
description: The novel technique is great news for Guam’s brown tree snakes, bad news for the island’s nesting birds.
content: In 2016, on the northern tip of Guam, two biologists, Tom Seibert and Julie Savidge, challenged several brown tree snakes to a battle of wits. The arena: a concrete pen with a narrow metal pole. The prize, at the top of the pole: two mice, a seed cake and a potato in a cage. (The potato and seed cake were for the mice.) The obstacle: a three-foot-tall metal stovepipe baffle cinched around the pole like a cummerbund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: N.B.A. Postpones Two More Games Because of the Virus
description: The N.B.A. has now postponed four games because of the virus, and said it would be meeting with its players’ union on Monday to discuss changes to health protocols.
content: The N.B.A. cited its coronavirus health protocols in postponing two games on Monday, bringing the total number of games postponed for this reason to four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Two Men Are Accused of Stealing Skulls From Florida Cemetery
description: The men said that they took the skulls to use in religious practices of Palo Mayombe, an African-Caribbean religion related to Santeria, according to the authorities.
content: Two men were arrested and accused of stealing the remains of military veterans from a Central Florida cemetery last month, in order to use them in religious practices, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio and Dave Philipps
title: Arrests have climbed in the days since the Capitol was overrun.
description: In the days since a mob of Trump supporters stormed the U.S. Capitol, federal and local authorities have arrested almost 100 people who they said were involved in the attack.
content: In the days since a mob of Trump supporters stormed the U.S. Capitol, federal and local authorities have arrested almost 100 people who they said were involved in the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Nick Saban Was Famous for Defense. Alabama’s Offense Is the Star Now.
description: The top-ranked team in college football will play for a championship on Monday with a dazzling offense. It wasn’t always that way for the team from Tuscaloosa.
content: [Follow our live score and game tracker of Alabama vs Ohio State.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Songs of Separation, and Lessons in Persian Cooking
description: The Under the Radar Festival entries “Capsule” and “Disclaimer” explore intimacy, isolation and identity. Bring your own fenugreek.
content: It’s funny to think about what we used to take for granted: that actors could see each other; that if the stage lights allowed, they could see the audience, too; that we could occupy the same space at the same time, living through the same event.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How big tech companies responded to the storming of the Capitol.
description: In the hours and days after a mob of President Trump’s loyalists stormed the Capitol, the nation’s biggest tech companies began to shut down accounts that helped incite the rampage. In the days and weeks before the attack, President Trump had used his Twitter feed and Facebook page to spread the lie that he had won the November election. It was that falsehood that helped drive the mob to the Capitol last Wednesday after a speech by the president.
content: In the hours and days after a mob of President Trump’s loyalists stormed the Capitol, the nation’s biggest tech companies began to shut down accounts that helped incite the rampage. In the days and weeks before the attack, President Trump had used his Twitter feed and Facebook page to spread the lie that he had won the November election. It was that falsehood that helped drive the mob to the Capitol last Wednesday after a speech by the president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Yardley
title: Pat Loud, Reality Show Matriarch of ‘An American Family,’ Dies at 94
description: A mother of five, she unapologetically laid bare the drama of her family life as a star of the first reality show.
content: Before “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills,” before the Kardashians, before the idea of living large and unscripted on camera became a TV staple, there was a startling program on public television called “An American Family” with a startling female character named Pat Loud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: The Palestinian Authority authorizes use of Russia’s Sputnik V vaccine.
description: The Palestinian Authority has given emergency authorization to Russia’s Sputnik V Covid-19 vaccine, Health Minister Mai al-Kaila announced  on Monday.
content: The Palestinian Authority has given emergency authorization to Russia’s Sputnik V Covid-19 vaccine, Health Minister Mai al-Kaila announced  on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Helene Cooper, Jennifer Steinhauer, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Luke Broadwater
title: Inside a Deadly Siege: How a String of Failures Led to a Dark Day at the Capitol
description: Poor planning among a constellation of government agencies and a restive crowd encouraged by President Trump set the stage for the unthinkable.
content: [Follow our live news on the Capitol Riots.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Beyond Impeachment, a Push for Ethics Laws That Do Not Depend on Shame
description: Congressional Democrats and a slew of groups are preparing to push for the kinds of ethics and governance changes not seen since the post-Watergate era.
content: WASHINGTON — As House Democrats move toward punishing President Trump with a history-making second impeachment, they are also pressing ahead with a parallel effort to try to ensure that Mr. Trump’s four-year record of violating democratic and constitutional norms cannot be repeated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 11, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 11, 2021.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 11, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: A state senator referred Rudy Giuliani for disbarment.
description: Citing his role in a “violent insurrectionist attack on the United States Capitol,” the chairman of the New York State Senate’s judiciary committee made a formal request on Monday to the state court system to begin the process of stripping President Trump’s lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, of his law license.
content: Citing his role in a “violent insurrectionist attack on the United States Capitol,” the chairman of the New York State Senate’s judiciary committee made a formal request on Monday to the state court system to begin the process of stripping President Trump’s lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, of his law license.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Antonella Francini
title: Catch a Fish in Paris. Post on Social Media. Release.
description: A new, younger generation of fishers is taking over the banks of the Seine, transforming a centuries-old tradition into an underground culture.
content: PARIS — On a recent wintry afternoon along the Seine, a Parisian teenager took a fishing rod out of a narrow holster, stuck a glittery rubber fish on a hook and cast his line into the water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Revealed: The Shipworm Sex Tapes
description: Nature’s weirdest clam surprises scientists once again, this time in video footage of its mating habits.
content: Above the water, September would seem a month like any other in the boatyards of Charleston, Ore., where yachts and wooden fishing vessels gently bob against a backdrop of emerald-green trees. But under the surface, specifically under the boats and inside the hulls, it is a very special time of year, when the wood-eating giant feathery shipworms jettison sperm and eggs into the open water in the hopes that their genes will live on in a new generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: On the Way Out, Melania Trump Denounces Attacks on Her as ‘Shameful’
description: After complaining about how she has been treated, the first lady also went on in a statement to condemn the violence at the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — After remaining silent for five days following the riot at the Capitol instigated by her husband, Melania Trump, the first lady, issued a statement on Monday complaining about how she had been treated before going on to condemn the deadly mob attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: intransigence
description: This word has appeared in 35 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: How Can ‘Jeopardy!’ Replace Alex Trebek? See Game-Show History
description: The same producer who helped Drew Carey succeed Bob Barker on “The Price Is Right” is now working on the “Jeopardy!” succession.
content: When Bob Barker left “The Price Is Right” after 35 years of giving out cars and vacations to Hawaii, many people wondered whether the show would survive.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s how the new small-business relief program start will work.
description: The Paycheck Protection Program reopens this week, and underserved borrowers — including women-led businesses and those run by Black, Latino and Asian owners and other minorities — will be first in line to tap the new funds, The New York Times’s Stacy Cowley reports.
content: The Paycheck Protection Program reopens this week, and underserved borrowers — including women-led businesses and those run by Black, Latino and Asian owners and other minorities — will be first in line to tap the new funds, The New York Times’s Stacy Cowley reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Baby Megalodons Were 6-Foot-Long Womb Cannibals, Study Suggests
description: The research appears to confirm that, even as newborns, the extinct sharks were very, very big.
content: In many ways, megalodons — the long-gone, leviathan predecessors of today’s sharks — had it made. Stretching up to 50 feet in length and weighing perhaps 110,000 pounds, they ruled the ancient seas with an iron fin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: We Worked Together on the Internet. Last Week, He Stormed the Capitol.
description: At BuzzFeed, we followed the signals of social media. A young employee followed them all the way to Charlottesville and Capitol Hill.
content: He fit in as well as anyone did at our Los Angeles studio, a place full of ambitious misfits with an unusual gift. They knew how to make web videos people wanted to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Kettles
description: It’s not just for boiling water — so choose something with a little style.
content: A kettle is equal parts kitchen workhorse and decorative accessory. So choosing one isn’t just a matter of finding something that can boil water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: The Crossword Stumper
description: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: The TABOR is a type of medieval drum. It is commonly accompanied by a small wind instrument called a pipe, and played by a one-person band. Pipe and TABOR players hang the drum from their left wrist, holding the pipe in their left hand, and use their right hand to beat the drum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: While fans watch Alabama and Ohio State duke it out, the host state Florida struggles with the coronavirus.
description: The east parking lot at Hard Rock Stadium has been a virus testing facility since March, closing for games for the N.F.L.’s Miami Dolphins and the University of Miami football teams. It also shut down for the Orange Bowl, though it is typically open seven days a week.
content: The east parking lot at Hard Rock Stadium has been a virus testing facility since March, closing for games for the N.F.L.’s Miami Dolphins and the University of Miami football teams. It also shut down for the Orange Bowl, though it is typically open seven days a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dera Menra Sijabat and Richard C. Paddock
title: ‘I’m Still Shocked’: Indonesian Airline Crash Shakes Small Fishing Village
description: A sleepy island has become a base for the aircraft search and recovery operation after Sriwijaya Air Flight 182 fell from the sky. “I’m lucky it didn’t hit me,” said one fisherman.
content: LANCANG ISLAND, Indonesia — Hendrik Mulyadi was checking his crab traps when he heard a huge explosion on the water nearby. The sea suddenly rose, lifting the Indonesian fisherman’s boat as smoke filled the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Melania Trump implores Americans to ‘stop the violence’ while also striking back at critics.
description: In her first public comments since rioters stormed the Capitol five days ago, Melania Trump, the first lady, said on Monday that she was “disappointed and disheartened with what happened last week” but did not address her husband’s role in encouraging the attack.
content: In her first public comments since rioters stormed the Capitol five days ago, Melania Trump, the first lady, said on Monday that she was “disappointed and disheartened with what happened last week” but did not address her husband’s role in encouraging the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Does Trump Face Legal Jeopardy for His Incendiary Speech Before the Riot?
description: The president’s actions just before his supporters’ deadly rampage at the Capitol has created new risks for him.
content: WASHINGTON — Scrutiny increased on Monday on how President Trump sought to foment anger at a rally of his supporters and then dispatched them to the Capitol shortly before they rioted last week, as House Democrats on Monday unveiled an article of impeachment accusing him of inciting an insurrection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: With State in Crisis, Cuomo Outlines Plan to ‘Win the Covid War’
description: Facing a daunting budget shortfall and a surging second wave, Gov. Andrew Cuomo unveiled New York’s agenda as state leaders seek help from Washington.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Facing a daunting budget crisis and a surging second wave of the coronavirus, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday unveiled his vision of New York’s agenda for the year, focused on righting the state’s finances and its citizens’ health in a moment of profound concern about the nation’s well-being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Ed Augustin and Kirk Semple
title: Pompeo Returns Cuba to Terrorism Sponsor List, Constraining Biden’s Plans
description: In announcing the move, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo cited Cuba’s hosting of American fugitives and Colombian rebels and its support for Venezuela’s authoritarian leader.
content: WASHINGTON — The State Department designated Cuba a state sponsor of terrorism on Monday in a last-minute foreign policy stroke that will complicate the incoming Biden administration’s plans to restore friendlier relations with Havana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: U.S. to Declare Yemen’s Houthis a Terrorist Group, Raising Fears of Fueling a Famine
description: The State Department’s terrorist designation may be more symbolic than searing for the rebel movement, but it could aggravate Yemen’s human catastrophe.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will designate the Houthi rebels in Yemen as a foreign terrorist organization, four U.S. officials familiar with the decision said on Sunday, deploying one of his last means of hard power against Saudi Arabia’s nemesis at the risk of exacerbating a famine in one of the world’s poorest nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Bill Pennington
title: Trump Golf Club Loses 2022 P.G.A. Championship
description: The golf major had been scheduled to be played at the Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J., in May 2022.
content: The P.G.A. of America, which conducts the P.G.A. Championship — one of golf’s four prestigious global major men’s championships — announced Sunday night that it would no longer hold its featured event at the Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J. It had been scheduled to be played there in May 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Can Andrew Yang Make It in New York City Politics?
description: Mr. Yang has name recognition, fund-raising ability and some different ideas on how to run a government. How will that play in a city ravaged by the pandemic?
content: In the last few months, the man who would be New York’s most famous mayoral candidate acted like anything but one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Pranshu Verma
title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Ukrainians Linked to Giuliani for Election Disinformation
description: The Treasury Department accused seven Ukrainians of working with a Russian agent “to spread misleading and unsubstantiated allegations” about President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration imposed sanctions on Monday against seven Ukrainians — including two who assisted President Trump’s personal lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani — for being part of what it called “a Russia-linked foreign influence network” that spread “fraudulent and unsubstantiated allegations” about President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. during the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David N. Cicilline
title: Why We Are Introducing an Article of Impeachment
description: One of the authors of the impeachment article against President Trump makes his case.
content: Since his resounding defeat in the presidential election in November, Donald Trump has done everything but concede to the democratic will of the American people. He unleashed an avalanche of lies and baseless claims of fraud — conspiracy theories that filled his supporters with a delusional belief that the election had been stolen from him. He filed a bevy of absurd lawsuits. He attempted to cajole and intimidate officials at all levels of government into subverting the election and keeping him in office. And then, running out of recourse, legitimate and illegitimate, he incited an insurrection against the government and the Constitution that he swore to uphold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Helene Cooper, Jennifer Steinhauer, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Luke Broadwater
title: How a string of failures led to the attack on the Capitol.
description: The chaos wrought by the siege on the Capitol last week revealed that the law enforcement agencies with jurisdiction had no coordinated plan to defend against an attack — especially one specifically aimed at powerful elected officials — despite warnings for years about the growing threat of domestic terrorism.
content: The chaos wrought by the siege on the Capitol last week revealed that the law enforcement agencies with jurisdiction had no coordinated plan to defend against an attack — especially one specifically aimed at powerful elected officials — despite warnings for years about the growing threat of domestic terrorism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Biden asks Congress about splitting days between impeachment and confirming his nominees and passing his agenda.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said he was exploring ways for Democrats in Congress to advance his agenda while pursuing a second impeachment of President Trump.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said he was exploring ways for Democrats in Congress to advance his agenda while pursuing a second impeachment of President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Antonella Francini
title: Corruption Trial of French-Israeli Tycoon Begins in Switzerland
description: Swiss prosecutors have accused the billionaire Beny Steinmetz of securing lucrative mining deals in the West African country of Guinea with bribes. Mr. Steinmetz has denied the charges.
content: A criminal court in Geneva on Monday began hearing charges of corruption and document forgery against the French-Israeli businessman Beny Steinmetz over the securing of lucrative mining deals in the West African country of Guinea, the latest chapter in a yearslong international investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Pang
title: It Took a Genocide for Me to Remember My Uighur Roots
description: Since 1949, the Chinese Communist Party has gradually established policies that threaten Uighur culture and identity. My family’s forced assimilation is a part of that story.
content: The first time I truly realized I was Uighur was just three years ago, when I saw the now-infamous viral photo of rows of Turkic men in dark blue uniforms, sitting in a concentration camp in Hotan, Xinjiang, a so-called Uighur autonomous region in China. Scanning the prisoners’ despondent faces, I was startled by their familiar features. Prominent cheekbones, round eyes, aquiline noses. My face was in theirs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: House Moves to Force Trump Out, Vowing Impeachment if Pence Won’t Act
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House would formally call on Vice President Mike Pence to invoke the 25th Amendment to strip President Trump of power, and move to impeach the president if he refused.
content: WASHINGTON — The House moved on two fronts on Sunday to try to force President Trump from office, escalating pressure on the vice president to strip him of power and committing to quickly begin impeachment proceedings against him for inciting a mob that violently attacked the seat of American government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Michael Crowley and Peter Baker
title: An impeachment charge against Trump is introduced as Biden considers a trial in the first days of his administration.
description: House Democrats on Monday introduced an article of impeachment against President Trump for inciting a mob that attacked the Capitol last week, vowing to press the charge as President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said he was considering splitting the first days of his administration between impeachment and advancing his agenda.
content: House Democrats on Monday introduced an article of impeachment against President Trump for inciting a mob that attacked the Capitol last week, vowing to press the charge as President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said he was considering splitting the first days of his administration between impeachment and advancing his agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: A Scramble to Boost Vaccinations in New York
description: Teachers, residents older than 75 and more medical workers can now get Covid-19 shots as the state eases its rules.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch live: Biden receives second vaccine dose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump Is Making Pence Look Good
description: Somewhat in the way that Keith Richards used to make the rest of the Rolling Stones look sober.
content: Gail Collins: Well Bret, we’ve just got a little more than a week left of the Trump presidency. Think we’ve got time for one more impeachment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Michael Madigan, the wily and venerable head of a dynasty, suspends his campaign to retain the speakership of the Illinois House.
description: Michael Madigan, the Democratic power broker who has served as Speaker of the Illinois House of Representatives for nearly four decades, has fallen short of the votes needed to remain in power — a reminder that Washington is not the only capital convulsed by postelection tumult.
content: Michael Madigan, the Democratic power broker who has served as Speaker of the Illinois House of Representatives for nearly four decades, has fallen short of the votes needed to remain in power — a reminder that Washington is not the only capital convulsed by postelection tumult.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Vaccine Rules Are Loosened a 2nd Time to Inhibit Waste
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 11, 2021.
content: “We’re seeing them in our office, and it just seems like we’re turning them away today just so we can call them back in a week and say, ‘Now you can get your vaccine.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Simon Rattle to Leave the London Symphony for Munich
description: As Brexit takes effect, Mr. Rattle, a British-born conductor with a family in Germany, said that he would take the helm of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra in 2023.
content: Simon Rattle, the acclaimed British-born conductor, returned to his home country several years ago to lead the London Symphony Orchestra — to fanfare and hopes of a new concert hall. But as Brexit takes effect and the prospects for that new hall remain far from certain, Mr. Rattle announced on Monday that he would leave in 2023 to take the helm of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra in Munich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Someone Etched ‘Trump’ on a Florida Manatee
description: Wildlife authorities are investigating and said that the harassment of the manatee was illegal under state and federal laws.
content: The sighting in Florida this week of a manatee with “Trump” etched in block letters on its back has prompted an investigation and a plea for help from a nonprofit conservation group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Hill, Arielle Ray and Dahlia Kozlowsky
title: ‘They Got a Officer!’: How a Mob Dragged and Beat Police at the Capitol
description: Videos show pro-Trump rioters pulling three officers down a set of stairs during a violent attempt to breach the building.
content: The Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol building by a pro-Trump mob left a police officer and a rioter dead. More than 50 members of the U.S. Capitol Police were injured, including 15 who required hospitalization, most of them with head wounds, according to Representative Tim Ryan, Democrat of Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: How High-End Restaurants Have Failed Black Female Chefs
description: Training and advancement as a chef can be hard to find in American fine-dining restaurants, according to Black women who have tried.
content: Eight years ago, Auzerais Bellamy landed what she thought was a big break: a stint as a stagiaire, or apprentice, at the French Laundry, Thomas Keller’s world-renowned restaurant in the Napa Valley. She wasn’t paid for her two days trailing the pastry team, but she saw it as an ideal training ground where, if asked to stay, she could learn from some of the best cooks in the business, sharpening her skills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Democrats controlling the White House and Congress will unlock fresh options as President-elect Joe Biden battles the pandemic.
content: President-elect Joe Biden will assume the presidency in nine days, and with it the responsibility of fighting a raging pandemic that is killing more than 3,000 Americans a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Business Rules the Trump Administration Is Racing to Finish
description: From tariffs and trade to the status of Uber drivers, regulators are trying to install new rules or reduce regulations before President-elect Joe Biden takes over.
content: In the remaining days of his administration, President Trump is rushing to put into effect a raft of new regulations and executive orders that are intended to put his stamp on business, trade and the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.5 Million Homes in California
description: A Tudor Revival home in Los Angeles, a modern house in Palm Springs and a hillside retreat in San Clemente.
content: This house, a few blocks south of Mulholland Drive in Laurel Canyon, was designed by Paul R. Williams, the first African-American member of the American Institute of Architects. Mr. Williams designed residences in Los Angeles for Frank Sinatra, Lucille Ball and other celebrities, as well as one of the first federally funded public housing complexes, in Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Hiltner
title: A Long, Lonesome Look at America
description: Alone on a 10,000-mile road trip across the United States, a Times journalist found an America cloaked in solitude — and a country on edge.
content: I was only a few days into a meandering trip across America, and already I was easing into something of a nighttime routine. Earlier in the day I’d pinpointed a promising campsite in Ozark National Forest. Now, I found myself ascending an isolated forestry road to get to it, my tires crackling over its rough, potholed surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Doug Pederson Fired as Philadelphia Eagles Coach
description: Less than three years after leading Philadelphia to its first Super Bowl win, Pederson was let go by the franchise ahead of an overhaul.
content: In a prelude to what could be a tumultuous off-season in Philadelphia, the Eagles on Monday fired their coach, Doug Pederson, less than three years after he led the team to its first Super Bowl championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: Michigan Commission bans open carry at the State Capitol.
description: The Michigan State Capitol Commission voted unanimously on Monday to ban the open carry of weapons in the state Capitol in Lansing. But gun owners with a concealed-weapons permit will still be able to carry concealed guns into the Capitol, and there will be restrictions on carrying guns on the Capitol grounds.
content: The Michigan State Capitol Commission voted unanimously on Monday to ban the open carry of weapons in the state Capitol in Lansing. But gun owners with a concealed-weapons permit will still be able to carry concealed guns into the Capitol, and there will be restrictions on carrying guns on the Capitol grounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Who Should Make the Online Rules?
description: A handful of unelected tech executives have tremendous influence on public discourse. Is that right?
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Are the Places in the World That You Love Most?
description: What places, either nearby or around the globe, bring you inspiration and comfort? What would you add to the Travel section’s “52 Places to Love in 2021”?
content: For the past many Januaries, The New York Times has published a Travel section mainstay: a list of 52 destinations around the world, complete with gorgeous photography. Last year’s list has the tagline “We picked destinations to inspire you, delight you and motivate you to explore the world,” and that applies to all the previous lists, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Resistance’ and ‘Finding Your Roots’
description: A historical drama with Jesse Eisenberg airs on Showtime. And House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is a guest on Henry Louis Gates, Jr.’s PBS docu-series.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 11-Jan. 17. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Alabama and Ohio officials begged fans to celebrate at home. It might not have worked.
description: The bar-lined Strip in Tuscaloosa, Ala., is usually filled with Crimson-clad football fans during championship games, who storm the street if the Crimson Tide win. The mayor of Tuscaloosa, the home city of the University of Alabama, was hoping that fans would stay home on Monday night as the city struggles with virus cases and limited capacity in hospitals.
content: The bar-lined Strip in Tuscaloosa, Ala., is usually filled with Crimson-clad football fans during championship games, who storm the street if the Crimson Tide win. The mayor of Tuscaloosa, the home city of the University of Alabama, was hoping that fans would stay home on Monday night as the city struggles with virus cases and limited capacity in hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kolker
title: Scared Straight or Scarred for Life?
description: In “Troubled,” Kenneth R. Rosen investigates the kind of tough-love programs he was placed in as a teenager and exposes their unusual methods.
